image.altText: Silhouettes of four people are seen in front of a purple background and a set of scales of justice

props.synopsis: After an inquiry lasting four-and-a-half years, the royal commission makes 222 recommendations for change in its final report and says "social transformation" is needed to improve the lives of people with disability.

title.children: Government responds to findings of disability royal commission

image.altText: A group of six women pose for a photo outside the front entrance to the WA Parliament.

props.synopsis: The chair of WA's elite athlete support organisation has leapt to the defence of its outgoing CEO amid criticism not enough had been done to deliver justice for dozens of former gymnasts who say they suffered physical and emotional abuse.

title.children: Delays in delivering justice to abused gymnasts not CEO's fault, WA Institute of Sport chair says

image.altText: Woodisde's Scarborough gas project includes expanding the current Pluto facility on the Burrup Peninsula

props.synopsis: Australia's reputation among international investors is on the line after the Scarborough gas project suffered a major legal blow, but it could pave the way for better consultation with traditional owners.

title.children: Industry leaders warn of 'big ripple effect' on Australian economy after Woodside defeat

image.altText: A military helicopter lands in bushland, kicking up clouds of dust.

props.synopsis: The Australian Defence Force's MRH-90 Taipan helicopter fleet — one of which was involved in a fatal military training exercise in the Whitsundays — has been retired early.

title.children: Australian Defence Force MRH-90 Taipan helicopters involved in fatal crash retired early

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: A road train travelling south along the Stuart Highway at sunset, south of Hayes Creek.

props.synopsis: An inquest into the death of a truck driver in WA's north has pointed to the dangers of non-regulation windscreen visors inside heavy vehicles.

title.children: Truckies' sun visors under scrutiny after worker hit and killed at roadhouse

image.altText: A close-up shot of a homemade marker pen gun in two pieces in a plastic ziplock bag.

props.synopsis: A working pen gun, designed to look like a common permanent marker, and a homemade machine gun are among items seized by police during separate raids on outlaw motorcycle gang members.

title.children: Gun disguised as permanent marker found by police during raid in Perth's south

image.altText: Andrews, Albanese and Palaszczuk sit at a long table with some papers talking, with others out of frame.

props.synopsis: Just two months ago, two of the strongest Labor leaders in recent history were solidly ensconced in WA and Victoria. They've now walked away.

title.children: Challenging times ahead for Labor and Albanese as another change of state leader looms on the horizon

image.altText: Black and white image of Whetoi Pomare

props.synopsis: Aotearoa New Zealand has had a treaty in place for almost two centuries but it wasn't until the 1970s that it was truly honoured. So what happened and what are the lessons for Australia ahead of the Voice referendum?

title.children: New Zealand reneged on its Treaty with Māori. Here's its pre-referendum message to Indigenous Australians

image.altText: hands hold an orange alarm clock against a blue background

props.synopsis: Here's your quick pocket guide on daylight saving as Australia comes into the warmer months.

title.children: When does daylight saving start? Here’s what time the clocks go forward and where

image.altText: Gambon as Albus Dumbledore, at Westminster Abby in 2018 and with Sacha Baron Cohen at the 2002 London Premiere

props.synopsis: Before Harry Potter, the veteran actor made his mark in stage dramas, satirical comedies and crime films.

title.children: Michael Gambon achieved an incredible amount before he put his stamp on Harry Potter

image.altText: a woman walks past a gallery wall filled with framed paintings

props.synopsis: From designing wrapping paper for department store giant Myer to pioneering art therapy at a Melbourne hospital and adopting digital art, landscape painter June Boase Weller has dedicated a lifetime to the arts.

title.children: Trailblazing painter June Boase Weller exhibition celebrates her 80 years in the arts

image.altText: A man wearing Brisbane Lions colours holds up a toddler.

props.synopsis: This year's grand final parade, which drew thousands of Brisbane Lions and Collingwood Magpies supporters into the precinct surrounding the MCG, returned to dry land after last year's event made its way down the Yarra on boats.

title.children: Thousands of supporters flock to Melbourne as AFL grand final parade returns to dry land

image.altText: A clean-shaven man wearing a blue polo shirt and cat smiles.

props.synopsis: European golfer Viktor Hovland got the Ryder Cup weekend off to a superb start with a rare hole in one — the problem was, it came a day early and wasn't even really a hole in one.

title.children: This golfer hit a hole in one in a par four at the Ryder Cup — here's why it didn't count

image.altText: A group of weaners feeding on hay in cattle yards

props.synopsis: Growers can now make hay while the sun shines after China lifted its two-year ban on hay exports.

title.children: Australian government welcomes China reprieve on hay exports

image.altText: The back of a policeman facing the felled tree with tape that says police line do not cross

props.synopsis: Photographs from the scene early on Thursday showed that the tree was cut down near the base of its trunk, in an apparent act of vandalism.

title.children: 16-year-old arrested after cutting down of iconic Robin Hood tree in northern England

image.altText: Trump grimaces as he speaks at a rally outside in the hot sun, with sweat visible on his face.

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Court rejects Donald Trump's bid to delay trial in wake of fraud ruling. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Overhead image of eggs stacked on top of colourful crates.

props.synopsis: West Australian egg farmers say they have an added challenge when it comes to boosting supply amid a national shortage.

title.children: Australia's love affair with eggs causes headaches as farmers push to expand

image.altText: screenshot truck

props.synopsis: How a distressed call with a British journalist led to the rescue of six migrant women in the back of a truck bound for Italy.

title.children: Migrants rescued from truck in France after panicked phone call with British journalist

image.altText: A phone screen showing the time 6.25 is in front of the analog flinders st station clock showing 6.20

props.synopsis: Recently found yourself five minutes late? Consider blaming it on a historic clock at Flinders Street Station.

title.children: Nobody had noticed when the ABC asked why the Flinders Street Station clock was running slow

image.altText: A photo at night of the broken down fire truck being loaded on to semi trailer.

props.synopsis: A strange and violent end to a bin fire inflames a row over what NSW firefighters say are "band-aid" fixes to an ageing truck fleet.

title.children: Fury after firefighters pelted with rocks while seeking cover in a broken-down truck

image.altText: A black background with various different cards falling. In focus is one card with Parliament House on it

props.synopsis: The Voice to Parliament referendum has been a major source of misinformation. As early voting opens next week, here are the key pieces of misinformation.

title.children: The Voice campaign has generated much misinformation. Here it is, debunked, all in one place

image.altText: Wesley Enoch, sitting on a rock in a park on a sunny day, looks at the camera with his hands clasped.

props.synopsis: The lead-up to the Voice referendum has taken a toll on the mental health of many people, especially in First Nations communities. Psychologists share their tips on how to manage stress and anxiety during a challenging time.

title.children: Do your friends and family disagree on the Voice? There are ways to manage that

image.altText: An image of book covers overlaid with blue and two robotic hands and arms

props.synopsis: Tech giants have been accused of "mass copyright infringement" and "system theft" by authors whose work has been used to train generative AI systems such as ChatGPT.

title.children: 'Outright theft': Furious Australian authors caught up in literary AI scandal

image.altText: tesla

props.synopsis: The US version of FairWork has launched a lawsuit against Elon Musk's Tesla, alleging "widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees". Meanwhile, the founder of Evergrande is under police watch, stoking fears the Chinese property giant is about to tank. Read all about today's business news on our live blog.

title.children: US regulator sues Tesla for 'racial harassment and retaliation', while Chinese property giant Evergrande's shares halted

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Bit of a shameless plug from myself here. In case you missed it, a story I did for TV this week about fuel efficiency standards (FES) and how there are concerns that regulators won't bring in strong enough laws. The FES are seen by some lobbyists as one of the best ways to push up electric vehicle adoption in Australia. Meanwhile, we have this story out today too on charging EVs. It looks into "range anxiety", and argues that this perception by some people that they shouldn't get an EV because it will be too hard to charge it is misguided.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: We've had quite a bit of EV news this week

featuredLink.title: So you want an electric car, but will you be able to charge it?

children.content: Bit of a shameless plug from myself here.
In case you missed it, a story I did for TV this week about fuel efficiency standards (FES) and how there are concerns that regulators won't bring in strong enough laws.
The FES are seen by some lobbyists as one of the best ways to push up electric vehicle adoption in Australia.

mediaThumbnail.caption: There are strong concerns that Australia will continue to be a dumping ground for dirty vehicles as accusations rise that Australia's biggest car manufacturer lobby group and car makers including Toyota, Hyundai are pushing for 'loopholes' in looming fuel efficiency laws. Australia is one of the only western countries without these standards. The sale of electric cars has been rising without fuel efficiency standards but they still only make up about 6 per cent of new car sales, with Tesla's sedan Model Y among the most popular models. The federal government argues the standards will get more electric cars into the Australia market, which will also help lower prices. But, it is still not clear what the final policy should look like and the debate is only getting more divisive.

The sale of electric cars has been rising without fuel efficiency standards but they still only make up about 6 per cent of new car sales, with Tesla's sedan Model Y among the most popular models. The federal government argues the standards will get more electric cars into the Australia market, which will also help lower prices. But, it is still not clear what the final policy should look like and the debate is only getting more divisive.

It looks into "range anxiety", and argues that this perception by some people that they shouldn't get an EV because it will be too hard to charge it is misguided.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some big news out of China. Shares in the Chinese property giant Evergrande have been halted. It has been battling solvency issues for at least a year. Its shares were halted after the developer said its founder Hui Ka Yan is being investigated over suspected "illegal crimes" and is under police watch. It's leading to more concerns from creditors about its ability to pay back enormous amounts of debt. Here is some copy from the news wire service Reuters: The world's most indebted property developer with more than $300 billion in total liabilities did not say whether Hui Ka Yan was still in a position to run the company, or what crimes he is being investigated for. The news signals for the first time that authorities could hold the billionaire Evergrande founder accountable for the developer's financial woes, which have ripped through the property sector that accounts for roughly a quarter of the Chinese economy. Deepening turmoil in China's debt-laden property sector is threatening to undermine Beijing's efforts to get the sputtering economy back on more solid footing, and raising fears among investors of a spillover into the country's banking system. The latest development is a major blow to China's once top-selling developer that has lurched from one crisis to another since its cash squeeze became public in 2021 and it defaulted on its offshore debt obligations later that year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chinese property giant Evergrande's shares halted

children.content: Some big news out of China.
Shares in the Chinese property giant Evergrande have been halted. It has been battling solvency issues for at least a year.
Its shares were halted after the developer said its founder Hui Ka Yan is being investigated over suspected "illegal crimes" and is under police watch.
It's leading to more concerns from creditors about its ability to pay back enormous amounts of debt.
Here is some copy from the news wire service Reuters:

The world's most indebted property developer with more than $300 billion in total liabilities did not say whether Hui Ka Yan was still in a position to run the company, or what crimes he is being investigated for.

The news signals for the first time that authorities could hold the billionaire Evergrande founder accountable for the developer's financial woes, which have ripped through the property sector that accounts for roughly a quarter of the Chinese economy.

Deepening turmoil in China's debt-laden property sector is threatening to undermine Beijing's efforts to get the sputtering economy back on more solid footing, and raising fears among investors of a spillover into the country's banking system.

The latest development is a major blow to China's once top-selling developer that has lurched from one crisis to another since its cash squeeze became public in 2021 and it defaulted on its offshore debt obligations later that year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Content warning: This post features discussion of racial abuse. Elon Musk's Tesla is being sued by the US version of FairWork for "tolerating widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees" from at least 2015 until today. The lawsuit was just filed by the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The regulator's suit contains some very concerning allegations that workers in its California factory endured racial abuse, stereotyping, and vilificaton including a range of racial slurs. "Slurs were used casually and openly in high-traffic areas and at worker hubs," they allege. It further alleges that workers faced graffiti around the factory that depicted racial abuse, "including variations of the N-word, swastikas, threats, and nooses, on desks and other equipment". This graffiti was even allegedly found on new electric cars as they were rolling off the production line. Further, it found people who raised objections to this, faced retaliation including being fired. The case was lodged by the EEOC's office in the tech hub of Silicon Valley and is being led by former FBI lawyer James Baker. Tesla has been contacted for comment. This suit follows another lawsuit by Californian-based regulators about similiar issues. Earlier this year, Tesla agreed to pay one worker several million dollars after a federal jury found it failed to prevent severe racial harassment at the Californian plant. Read more of the suit here .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tesla sued by US regulator for 'racial harassment and retaliation'

children.content: Content warning: This post features discussion of racial abuse.
Elon Musk's Tesla is being sued by the US version of FairWork for "tolerating widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees" from at least 2015 until today.
The lawsuit was just filed by the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
The regulator's suit contains some very concerning allegations that workers in its California factory endured racial abuse, stereotyping, and vilificaton including a range of racial slurs.
"Slurs were used casually and openly in high-traffic areas and at worker hubs," they allege.
It further alleges that workers faced graffiti around the factory that depicted racial abuse, "including variations of the N-word, swastikas, threats, and nooses, on desks and other equipment".
This graffiti was even allegedly found on new electric cars as they were rolling off the production line.
Further, it found people who raised objections to this, faced retaliation including being fired.
The case was lodged by the EEOC's office in the tech hub of Silicon Valley and is being led by former FBI lawyer James Baker.
Tesla has been contacted for comment.

This suit follows another lawsuit by Californian-based regulators about similiar issues. Earlier this year, Tesla agreed to pay one worker several million dollars after a federal jury found it failed to prevent severe racial harassment at the Californian plant.
Read
more of the suit here

image.altText: A mid-shot of Kate Chaney speaking into a microphone at a podium indoors, wearing a purple jacket and white top.

props.synopsis: The sister of federal WA MP Kate Chaney, Dr Anna Chaney, is confirmed as a victim of an alleged axe attack in North Perth.

title.children: WA MP Kate Chaney's sister injured in alleged axe attack at Perth medical centre

image.altText: Close up of Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce speaking to the media at a press event.

props.synopsis: A parliamentary committee investigating the government's rejection of extra Qatar Airways flights is increasing its rhetoric in a bid to land high-profile witnesses.

title.children: Senator claims former Qantas boss Alan Joyce could face jail if he avoids airline inquiry

image.altText: Hospital staff in scrubs run.

props.synopsis: A teenage girl dies from her injuries after a lone gunman in Rotterdam shoots her and her mother at their house and a teacher at a university hospital.

title.children: Medical student gunman kills three, including teenage girl, during Rotterdam shooting

image.altText: Michael Gambon as Dumbeldore in Harry Potter

props.synopsis: Michael Gambon, who played Dumbledore in Harry Potter, has died peacefully in hospital, according to a family statement.

title.children: Harry Potter actor Sir Michael Gambon dies aged 82

image.altText: Next to just visible blue pool water, a woman with sunglasses and stripy top lays with phone held over her face.

props.synopsis: If you're trying to change bad habits at work or home, this expert says ignore the traditional approaches to changing behaviour.

title.children: This behavioural scientist says the key to better habits is more celebrations and less abstractions

image.altText: Sheep looking at camera in sale yard pen.

props.synopsis: As sheep prices continue to plummet across the country, more than 20 agricultural organisations have co-signed a letter to the prime minister, urging the government not to ban live exports of the animal.

title.children: Farmers say live export ban will jeopardise trade relationship as prices continue to fall

image.altText: Several countries, an ocean and a large amount of cloud, seen from space.

props.synopsis: A hybrid weather system, this "Mediterranean hurricane" is already responsible for more than 11,000 deaths and massive damage bills — this is how it forms and why we could see them intensify in future.

title.children: The world's deadliest storm to strike this year was a monster — and the 'medicane' could be getting worse
